Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: A Scalable Search Tool for Interesting Patterns in Scientific Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Across many scientific disciplines, the availability of very large
amounts of data is creating a paradigm shift. The goal of this project
is to develop Scolopax, a tool for finding interesting patterns in
classification and prediction models trained on large high-dimensional
data. These patterns can capture previously unknown relationships
between the variables of a complex process, hence are essential for
exploratory analysis and scientific discovery.

This project explores several research directions to lay the
foundations for Scolopax: (1) Design of a new query language that can
express all common pattern search preferences. (2) Algorithms for
learning a query so that even non-technical users can formulate
non-trivial queries through an interactive process. (3) New rewrite
rules and efficient data management approaches to automatically
transform queries into fast implementations on a cluster or Cloud. (4)
Design of new semi-parametric data mining techniques that are amenable
to scalable training, evaluation, and pattern confidence computation.

User-friendly query writing functionality makes Scolopax accessible to
scientists and citizen scientists alike. Its planned deployment
through popular Web sites, e.g., those hosted by the Cornell Lab of
Ornithology, has the potential to enable new scientific
discoveries. By letting citizen scientists not only contribute data,
but also make their own discoveries using the data, Scolopax also
serves as an important enabler and motivator for outreach programs and
greater involvement of citizen scientists. For further information see
the project web site at the URL:
http://www.ccs.neu.edu/home/mirek/Projects/Scolopax

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Scolopax project emerged from a collaboration between computer scientists, statisticians, and bird ecologists. It focused on the development of novel techniques for exploratory analysis of big data. Results include near-optimal parallel algorithms for finding relationships (including correlations), a new data mining technique, called STEM, that is able to exploit spatio-temporal relationships for improving prediction quality, and the Scolopax Web application, which enables non-technical users to search for interesting patterns in massive high-dimensional data. In addition to publications in top-tier peer-reviewed computer science research venues, results obtained using the approaches developed by this project are starting to have an impact in ecology and society beyond academia. In particular, bird distribution models created using STEM were used in the 2013 State of the Birds Report on Private Lands and Waters (by the US Department of the Interior) and in the 2013 report on Species Distribution Modeling of Priority Bird Species on Bureau of Land Management Lands to Determine Stewardship Responsibility for Conservation Planning. STEM results were also used in the BirdReturns program, an innovative new approach to align the interests of bird conservationists and farmers in California's Central Valley as reported in the New York Times in April, 2014 (http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/15/science/paying-farmers-to-welcome-birds.html).

The Scolopax project provided funding and research opportunities to graduate students, including a female computer science PhD student and two female computer science Masters students. Results of this project feature prominently in a graduate computer science class on parallel processing of Big Data at Northeastern University in Boston, MA.

Technical highlights of this project include the following:

1. Novel parallel join techniques to discover relationships in big data, e.g., similar or dissimilar behavior of bird species in different regions or habitats: Our research focused on minimizing the time it takes to compute the desired results on a cluster of computers, including resources available through Cloud computing. We proved lower bounds for this problem, showing for a large class of applications that there are non-trivial inherent computational delays no matter how many machines are available. We also designed novel solutions that we showed analytically and experimentally to be close to this lower bound.

2. STEM and AdaSTEM data mining techniques: These data mining techniques extend traditional non-parametric techniques to exploit spatio-temporal properties, which are common in many applications. As a result, STEM achieves greater prediction accuracy than previous work. AdaSTEM further address data sparseness and skew, which are common challenges in observational data reported by citizen scientists and data collected through crowdsourcing. STEM and AdaSTEM were crucial for producing the highly accurate models of bird occurrence that were used in government reports. Both techniques were designed for efficient parallel training and predictions.

3. Data transfer reduction: Communication cost often hampers parallel computation on big data. This project developed novel techniques that reduce communication cost through lazy function evaluation that is enabled through syntactic rewriting of a given parallel program. It complements traditional compression techniques and can be used together with them for greater effect.

4. Interactive refinement of imprecise queries: We proposed novel measures of result sensitivity based on ranking similarity measures from Web search; and we designed efficient techniques for estimating them in real-time. This helps users refine uncertain search conditions when they are looking for relevant results in a big collection of structured data.
